title: 104_hr1497
content: The Act titled "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" revises the limitation on deduction of policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" amends the deduction limitation for policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. The deduction for any taxable year is capped at 90% of policyholder dividends or 30% of life insurance. The deduction limitation for policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies is capped at 90% of policyholder dividends or 30% of life insurance company taxable income, with a minimum limit of $35,000,000 for any taxable year. The deduction limitation for policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies is capped at 90% of policyholder dividends or 30% of taxable income, with a minimum limit of $35,000,000 for any taxable year. Stock life insurance companies are treated as mutual if they meet certain criteria regarding stock ownership. The text chunk discusses the ownership criteria for stock life insurance companies to be treated as mutual, requiring at least 80% ownership by mutual life insurance companies. Section 809 is repealed. The ownership criteria for stock life insurance companies to be treated as mutual is discussed, requiring at least 80% ownership by mutual life insurance companies. Section 809 of the Code is repealed. The tax-exempt interest policyholders' share is amended in various sections of the Code, including sections 807, 812, 817, and 842. The tax-exempt interest policyholders' share is amended in sections 807, 812, 817, and 842 by striking and inserting specific subsections and paragraphs. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1994, except for recomputation under section 809(f). The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1994. It does not affect the application of section 809(f) for taxable years before January 1, 1995. Capital losses after December 31, 1994, cannot be carried back for life insurance companies under section 808(b)(2). No capital loss from a taxable year after December 31, 1994, can be carried back to a year before January 1, 1995 for life insurance companies subject to the limitation under section 808(b)(2) of the tax code. Small life insurance companies are exempt from capitalizing certain policy acquisition expenses as per an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This exemption applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1994. Additionally, there is a provision in the tax code that prohibits carrying back capital losses from a taxable year after December 31, 1994, to a year before January 1, 1995 for life insurance companies under section 808(b)(2). The Congress intends for increased revenues from the amendments to be used for deficit reduction, tax incentives for small life insurance companies, and programs benefiting children's nutrition, education, housing, and family support.
